thread.title: Sign of the times? $100,000 cruise nearly sells out in a day
thread.title_full: Sign of the times? $100,000 cruise nearly sells out in a day

author: Gene Sloan , USA TODAY
title: Sign of the times? $100,000 cruise nearly sells out in a day
text:
The 490-passenger Seven Seas Navigator at anchor in the tropics. (Photo: Regent Seven Seas Cruises)
Tags Seven Seas Navigator Regent Seven Seas Cruises 276 CONNECT 132 TWEET 14 LINKEDIN 29 COMMENT EMAIL MORE Now we know where the 1% is taking their vacation in 2017: On a cruise ship.
Nearly three quarters of cabins on an epic, around-the-world sailing unveiled last month by luxury line Regent Seven Seas were booked within hours of the announcement despite a price tag in excess of $100,000 per couple, an executive for the line's parent company revealed this week in a conference call to discuss second quarter earnings.
"This cruise has proven so popular that 70% of the voyage was booked on the very first day of sales," Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings president and CEO Frank Del Rio said during the call with Wall Street analysts. "This is a testament not only to the allure of the Regent brand, but also to our belief that guests ... want unique, different, and rich destination experiences."
Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings is the parent company of Regent as well as Norwegian Cruise Line and Oceania Cruises.
Kicking off Jan. 5, 2017 in Miami, the 128-day sailing on the 490-passenger, all-suite Seven Seas Navigator will be Regent's first around-the-world cruise in six years and one of its most ambitious voyages ever. It include stops in more than 60 ports across six continents.
USA TODAY
A suite the size of a house? This ship will have one
Fares for the trip start at $54,999 per person, based on double occupancy (or $109,998 per couple), for a room that measures 301 square feet. Slightly larger rooms that measure 359 square feet range in price from $129,998 to $151,998 per couple. Bigger suites range from $211,998 to $319,998 per couple.
The fares include a pre-cruise hotel stay, first class airfare to and from Miami, exclusive shore-side events, unlimited Internet on the ship and several other perks.
Operating three relatively small ships, Regent is one of several cruise lines that cater to the high-end luxury travel market. For a deck-by-deck tour of one of its vessels, click through the carousel below.
Luxury line Regent's 700-passenger Seven Seas Mariner, shown here in a file photo, recently emerged from a major makeover in dry dock that brought significant changes to cabins and public areas. Regent Seven Seas Mariner Fullscreen The 709-by-93-foot Seven Seas Mariner was the world's first all-suite, all-balcony cruise ship when it debuted in 2001 and still is considered one of the most luxurious vessels afloat. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Originally built for Radisson Seven Seas Cruises, which became Regent Seven Seas Cruises in 2006, the Seven Seas Mariner was constructed at the Chantiers de L'Atlantique shipyard in St. Nazaire, France. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Seven Seas Mariner's main pool deck received upgrades during the overhaul of the ship that included new mosaic tile work. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The teak-lined main pool deck is home to three whirlpools in addition to a salt water main pool. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Lounge chairs surround the main pool on three sides. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Among luxury touches on the Seven Seas Mariner, lounge chairs are covered in plush towel-like fabric during the day. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen More lounge chairs are located along the sides of the ship's top deck. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Located at the front of the the Seven Seas Mariner on Deck 12, the Observation Lounge offers sweeping views over the bow of the ship. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Observation Lounge was completely revamped during the recent overhaul of the Seven Seas Mariner with rich ivory, ebony and white tones. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The stylish, back-lit bar at the Observation Lounge. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Located mid-ship on Deck 5, the Mariner Lounge is one of the vessel's hubs for nightly entertainment. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Mariner Lounge offers comfortable seating and views of the ocean. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The bar at the Mariner Lounge. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A grand piano in the Mariner Lounge is the site of nightly live entertainment. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Another hot spot on the Seven Seas Mariner is the Stars Lounge, located mid-ship on Deck 6. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Stars Lounge features comfortable seating and ocean views, and at night turns into the ship's nightclub. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The bar at the Stars Lounge. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Also revamped during the overhaul of the Seven Seas Mariner was the Horizon Lounge, located at the back of the ship on Deck 6. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Seven Seas Mariner has a central Atrium that serves as a interior hub for the ship and is home to reception and destination desks. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Glass elevators soar through the eight-deck-high Atrium. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The main stairway in the Seven Seas Mariner's Atrium has a curvy, modern design. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The 580-seat Constellation Lounge is the main showroom on Seven Seas Mariner and features plush seating with unobstructed views. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The main restaurant on Seven Seas Mariner is Compass Rose, which serves European-inspired Continental cuisine. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Like all the restaurants on Seven Seas Mariner, Compass Rose is available at no extra charge. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Among several specialty restaurants on the Seven Seas Mariner is Prime 7, an elegant steakhouse serving prime cuts of beef as well as seafood options. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Fine wines on display for diners in a glass case are among the allures of Prime 7. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Freshly renovated in rich gold and blue tones, Signatures is a reservations-required, 84-seat French-specialty dining venue on Deck 6. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Coffee and snacks are available around the clock on Deck 6. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Located on Deck 4, a small casino offers blackjack, roulette, stud poker, mini-craps and slot machines. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Seven Seas Mariner's casino opens when the ship is at sea. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The small slot machine area in the Seven Seas Mariner' casino. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Every suite on the Seven Seas Mariner was refreshed during the recent makeover with new furnishings, upholstery and custom-milled carpeting. Here, a Deluxe Veranda Suite -- the most common of the ship's 350 rooms. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen At 301 square feet, including the balcony, the Seven Seas Mariner's Deluxe Veranda Suites are among the largest standard cabins at sea. In addition to a bed area, they feature a separate sitting area with a sofa, table and desk. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Every Seven Seas Mariner suite opens up onto a private balcony. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Bathrooms in Deluxe Veranda Suites are lined in marble with stone countertops. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Deluxe Veranda Suite bathrooms have large walk-in showers. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The toilet area of a Deluxe Veranda Suite bathroom. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Deluxe Veranda Suite bathrooms feature L'Occitane toiletries. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A built-in vanity desk is located just outside the bathroom in Deluxe Veranda Suites. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Even the smallest rooms on the Seven Seas Mariner such as the Deluxe Veranda Suite feature walk-in closets. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Walk-in closets in Deluxe Veranda Suites offer a private safe. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A small table next to the bed in Deluxe Veranda Suites features a phone. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Electrical outlets in Seven Seas Mariner suites accept both U.S.-style and Europe-style plugs. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Miniature refrigerators in every suite are stocked with complimentary sodas, beer and water. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen All Seven Seas Mariner suites come with DVD players. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen An outdoor promenade on Deck 6 offers passengers a chance to stroll in the open air. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The back third of the Seven Seas Mariner's top deck area is devoted to activities such as shuffleboard, golf putting and croquet. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Deck-top activities include a putting green with artificial turf. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Golf clubs and balls are available around-the-clock on deck. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Seven Seas Mariner also features a golf driving range station on Deck 12 for practicing swings. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A netted-in tennis court is located at the back of the ship. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen An area for croquet and bocce also is located on the sports deck. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Bocce balls are available for play on the Bocce court. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Day beds in a shady area atop the Seven Seas Mariner. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Seven Seas Mariner features a stylish, contemporary decor, as can be seen in this view of an elevator hall. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Seven Seas Mariner library is located on Deck 6 and offers a large selection of fiction and non-fiction hardbacks that can be borrowed during sailings. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Seven Seas Mariner library also stocks a wide variety of games. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Passengers also will find a large selection of movies on DVD in the library that they can borrow to play in their suites at no cost. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Next to the library on Deck 6 are two card rooms that double as a conference space. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The unusually large card rooms are used for everything from bridge lectures and tournaments to corporate meetings. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Cabin decks feature complimentary, self-serve laundry rooms with washers, dryers and ironing tables. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Duty free shops located on Deck 7 of the Seven Seas Mariner offer Regent Seven Seas Cruises logo wear, jewelry, perfumes, swim wear, designer resort wear and precious stones. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Among the luxury touches on Seven Seas Mariner are complimentary shore excursions, which can be arrange at the Destination Services desk located on Deck 5. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The reception desk is located on Deck 5. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A concierge desk located at the bottom of the central Atrium on Deck 5. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Seven Seas Mariner is home to an extensive art collection, including this piece located just outside the Horizon Lounge. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The hallway leading to the Horizon Lounge boasts circular windows looking out over the sea. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Another small outdoor seating area on the Seven Seas Mariner is located on Deck 6 just outside the Horizon Lounge. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The pool grill, located near the main pool, features a buffet area with fruit, salads and other items. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A desert table at the outdoor Pool Grill. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Fruit salad and other snacks at the open-air Pool Grill, which is located just steps away from the pool. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A seating area at the open-air Pool Grill, which serves burgers, fish sandwiches and other made-to-order grill items. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A seating area on Seven Seas Mariner. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A buoy atop the Seven Seas Mariner. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Like this topic?
